DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Home, An Ordinary Upper-Middle Class House
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega allegedly earned millions helping Colombia's cocaine lords launder drug profits, but if that's true he didn't put too much of it into his house. Compared to the extravagant mansions customary among Latin American dictators, the Noriega house is modest _ a two-story affair in a neat, upper middle-class neighborhood. Its walls are painted white and topped by a red tile roof, classic tropical architecture. ``He would only say `Hello,' very respectfully,'' said German Sanchez, 53, who was the military leader's next-door neighbor 16 years but was never formally introduced to him. ``You may think what you like of Noriega, but we can't say he was anything but respectful toward his neighbors,'' he said. Sanchez's house is between Noriega's and a smaller house on a corner that Noriega also owned. ``The servants and guests stayed there,'' Sanchez said. Reporters allowed into the house Saturday did not find any evidence of voodoo or black magic, which Noriega was rumored to have practiced. But the general apparently admired Napoleon Bonaparte and hung two pictures of the French emperor in his second-story study. The house wraps around three sides of a 45-square-foot courtyard where a stone fountain was bubbling water. A small room had been converted into a chapel. A six-foot crucifix hung on a wall behind an altar. An oil painting of St. George slaying the dragon hung on another wall. Noriega seemed to be in the Christmas spirit. An eight-foot Christmas tree trimmed with stuffed dolls and other adornments stood in a back terrace, next to a manger. About two dozen cardboard boxes and black plastic garbage bags were stuffed with toys, games and gifts for children. U.S. troops stormed the Noriega family home Wednesday, using stun grenades that shattered glass jalousies and hand-painted vases and flowerpots. All the windows in Noriega's bedroom were blown away, as was most of the ceiling over his king-size bed. One of two walk-in closets held a combination safe and a locked metal strongbox. The safe was open and empty, with two plastic bags of dehumidifying crystals inside. A bullet destroyed the keyhole of the metal cabinet. A U.S. soldier assigned to guard the house picked up a wooden plaque with ``Battalion 2000'' painted on it. That is the elite unit Noriega named in honor of the year Panama is to take over the Panama Canal. It is not clear how much Noriega used the house recently. He was reportedly sleeping in different locations every night, fearing coup attempts. Little is known of his personal life. Sanchez, a lawyer and member of the board of directors of the Panamanian Chamber of Commerce, said he had just arrived home from a cocktail party early Wednesday when the U.S. attack began. ``About five minutes before that, two small cars with armed men inside rode up to the house and then everybody left right away,'' Sanchez said.
